Does this mean that we treat any cross referenced PR as a depends on even if there is no Depends-On flag? Seems that we only search for the url of this change in other changes. I think that may contribute to the issue you are seeing in that it is too greedy in its match.

Maybe we can relax the check below if we add an explicit check for depends-on?
Yes, looks like, but while maybe reducing the error cases refining the search won't solve the underlying problem. So I think we could refine it but that would be a separate change.

This value should be subpath/project which getProject supports fine. However, should we be using the fully qualified canonical name here including the github url as well? That way if a project with the same name is somehow in the same tenant from two different sources we avoid conflicts?

To do that I think you can replace proj here with url less the scheme? It could also be that I am overthinking this.

good catch, we should use the canonical name here, but not from the url but from self.canonical_hostname. You can construct a Project object here using proj and self.source and let the Project object calculate the canonical name.

nova/scheduler/client/report.py.message:
If we change the version in a_c don't we have to change the version in put allocation as well? I mean during claim_resources most of the cases we use the same version as the in the a_c but except when we need to handle evacuation, there we get the current allocation _with a different_ version that this from placement. See 
* https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1566
* https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1595
* https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1609

While based on the test results this change works I think it  would be safer to use the same MAPPING_VERSION microversion at https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1567 as well.

> If we change the version in a_c don't we have to change the version
 > in put allocation as well?

The only difference in PUT/POST /allocations* from previous microversions is that it allows (but ignores) the 'mappings' field. So unless we've saved the allocation *candidate* off somewhere (which I suppose we might have to do later to fix the revert_resize thing) the *allocations* we're using in all the other places could theoretically just be sent down with an older microversion.

However, that's not what's happening. Any time we PUT allocations that were retrieved via GET /allocation_candidates, we use the microversion gleaned from the third value in the tuple returned by this method, which ends up as allocation_request_version in the code you've linked.

 > * https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1566

GET /allocations is unchanged at the new microversion. (Importantly, it does *not* return mappings -- how could it?)

 > * https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1595

This method does consume the allocation request returned by GET /a_c, but it peels out the allocations and uses them to assemble the new payload...

 > * https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1609

...so this payload won't have 'mappings' in it.

 > While based on the test results this change works I think it  would
 > be safer to use the same MAPPING_VERSION microversion at
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b953db09e8b9195c6a922c03a57f44cd790adcb6/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L1567
 > as well.

That would imply that we're expecting something different from that GET at the new microversion. We're not.

(I thought you were going to say we should use the new microversion for all PUTs/POSTs to be safe, e.g. just in case _move_operation_alloc_request wasn't stripping the mappings out. But we already are, via the allocation_request_version.)
Thanks for the explanation. I rest my case.

Is the scope of the problem description also including ci/qe automation? I would assume "yes", based on this paragraph.
we do already have tripleo-upgrade. How does that fit in here? Is this work a replacement for that, or would we move tripleo-upgrade to be part of this supported automation?

TBD. I believe tripleo-upgrade is under the covers of some tripleo commands. If that's the case, nothing changes. If we're recommended that tripleo-upgrade be used in automation, then we'd probably want to pull in tripleo-upgrade into this repo.

This is an admirable goal, but doesn't always work out to be practical. A review of infrared's code will quickly show how many workarounds are in place that depend on specific versions of TripleO/OSP. Perhaps we should try a branchless approach, but make room to perhaps branch per major version of the code-base, and have the major version match to minimum supported release?

We could then have *some* flexibility to do actions differently per release of TripleO, but we're still able to remove old cruft at some point instead of being forced to carry code for old versions indefinitely.

OK, so as I understand it the drive would be to push anything that requires version/branch awareness up into the product itself regardless of whether it's specifically some sort of CI workaround for a special case due to the CI environment?

Yes we would like thing addressed in the upstream code base and not worked around in the CI frameworks.  Now there will be some version specific things that we'll need to handle in these roles/modules to handle the differences when performing actions across the various version. However that should help us identify when we break backwards compatibility or create an awkward UX.
I agree w/ Jesse,

I disagree. Quickstart is branchless and we don't necessarily have work arounds for versions. I think that's an issue with how infrared has decided to patch things.  We will need to include some version aware code so that we can throw errors or handle specific cases for the affected versions, however "workarounds" implies that there's a solution that as not properly pushed upstream.

For upgrades for example the workflow diverges from some releases (we managed to keep it more the less homogeneous from Pike to Rocky but for Stein it's pretty different). In tripleo-upgrade we addressed these differences by branching but if the new repo will be branchless we'll need to come up with a clever way to not end up with a role full of flag conditions depending on the version.

How do you plan to address the differences between workflows in the different versions?

Will you use flags to specify what commands should run in a certain version of tripleo?

We could branch things however we would have started much sooner order for it to make sense. We could do our own branches/tags if we want to manage that however I believe the goal should be branchless (but version aware) for now.

Since we're writing the automation for specific elements, some of this is up to the end user to put together the correct workflow items. We'd be providing the individual pieces. So the version specific nature would be around a command's individual options.  We'll likely have a version flag that can be used by each role to coordinate what is available/validate the requested options. We wouldn't have a role that would be like "install undercloud, load images, do container setup, deploy overcloud. Those would likely be 4 separate roles or modules.
i also think branchless could lead to a lot of flag conditions, as seems to be the pattern in infrared and quickstart today.

While it is implied in the problem description, there should be some sort of commitment from people involved in the other tools to converge on using the base roles provided by the new repo.

Otherwise we could turn this effort into https://xkcd.com/927/

True, except the goal is external operators who are writing their own and not necessarily consuming quickstart/infrared/etc.  Those tools would benefit from this effort but isn't exactly the target as written.  This one is to establish an officially supported set of roles that can be consumed by our tooling or end users's tooling.  We support quickstart for upstream efforts but we don't package it in anyway so the only way to to consume it is via source. This is to establish something that we do officially ship/support/manage for users.

I kind of imagined that the modules would only act as wrappers for the individual tripleo commands and the roles would more or less provide a certain functionality using the modules, kind of like Alex suggests. So you'd call the role with the following in your playbook:

  include_role:
    role: overcloud
    tasks_from: update
    vars:
      environment_files:
        - network_isolation.yaml
        - ceph_storage.yaml
      overcloud_roles:
        - Controller
        - Networker
        - Compute
        - CephStorage

And you'd have overcloud/tasks/update.yaml implement the modules in the following order (and excuse the over-simplification of the params and process):

  - tripleo_overcloud_update_prepare:
      environment_files: "{{ environment_files }}"
      param: value
      ...

  - tripleo_overcloud_update_run:
      limit: "{{ items }}"
      param: value
      ...
    loop: "{{ overcloud roles }}"

  - tripleo_overcloud_cephupgrade_run:
      param: value
      ...

  - tripleo_overcloud_update_converge
      environment_files: "{{ environment_files }}"
      param: value
      ...

Alex, is this more or less along the line of what you were aiming do to?

I think it depends on where we draw the line for the external interface. I was thinking about this and I think roles might be better way to expose the functionality rather than modules themselves.  The role can contain task files for specific functions. For example if we had a role that encapsilated the undercloud, we can expose things like:

  include_role:
    role: undercloud
    tasks_from: install


  include_role:
    role: undercloud
    tasks_from: update


  include_role:
    role: undercloud
    tasks_from: upgrade


Rather than having to write modules for each of these and the user have to specify the parameters, we can hide some of that complexity by just exposing specific roles and task files.

If we only expose modules we end up getting something like...


  tripleo_undercloud_install:
     var1: foo
     var2: bar
     ....
     var12: baz


  tripleo_undercloud_update:
     var1: foo
     var2: bar
     ....
     var12: baz


  tripleo_undercloud_upgrade:
     var1: foo
     var2: bar
     ....
     var12: baz


Just a thought...

We don't want people using the internals directly. This is not a recommended usage. Some of the things that we have like ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image could be used by a user, but they are very complex and hard for an end user to actually consume. IMHO tripleo-ansible is the equivalent of the old puppet modules where a user can build their cloud using just those, but you wouldn't use puppet-tripleo directly because it assumes much of the rest of tripleo is being used.

The overall benefit is that we don't end up with...

https://github.com/redhat-openstack/infrared/tree/master/plugins/tripleo-overcloud
https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/src/branch/master/roles
https://github.com/cjeanner/tripleo-lab/tree/master/roles

None of which are compatible with each other and all implement various levels of functionality in opinionated ways.

The generation of templates will not be part of these roles as that is something we expect a customer to handle external. The target is only to wrap the tripleo functions and not necessarily the other items that an operator might want to do (generate ssl, build network templates, etc).  This will also help highlight gaps in the tripleo tooling where we expect end users to perform complex actions but don't have a way to assist or do it for them.  Today these efforts get hidden in CI frameworks and not raised as possible improvements to the tripleo functionality.

The idea of these roles is not necessarily to completely replace the overall functionality provided in infrared/quickstart/tripleo-lab, but rather align them to all do things like undercloud install, overcloud deploy in the exact same way and let end users do it too. The general playbooks that each use will likely still contain some specific actions (template generation, etc) but the actual execution of the tripleo function will be identical with each. This helps reduce troubleshooting issues when we go between tools and we have to figure out how each invokes the commands.

tripleo-ansible = internal roles for the actual framework deploymgnt

Oh, it's just the way we're using skopeo and also giving it an explicit host.  If you specify a fully-qualified name as input, this command would be something like:

  skopeo copy some-url docker://localhost:1234/docker.io/foo/bar

Clearly skopeo has to take localhost:1234 as the host, so docker.io/foo/bar must be the repository name.  But we want to strip docker.io from there so it goes in un-namespaced.
Once we do that, "docker pull docker.io/foo/bar" and "docker pull foo/bar" will work as expected.  As will "podman pull".

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ku.message:
This method is called from more than one place.
_perform_app_rollback
_perform_app_recover
perform_app_apply
perform_app_remove

Do the other methods also need special handling for  PlatformHelmFailure?

I check if the operation is APP_APPLY_OP so, perform_app_remove and _perform_all_rollback don't ever raise the exception.

For perform_app_apply, there is little difference between the function raising an exception and returning False. The exception will be caught by the generic "except Exception as e" and it will just log the exception.

For _perform_app_recover, the function is again called last before the "try-except" block is finished, but this time in case the function returned false, the rc variable was set to false. So I also specifically catch this exception and set the rc variable to false as well.

Detecting this here seems like a bit of a hack to me. If this is just a race condition where the kubernetes pods are not quite ready after a reboot, then I can think of a couple other approaches:
1. Have a general hold-off period after a reboot before attempting to apply any apps (e.g. check if uptime is at least 3 minutes or something).
2. Update the _met_app_apply_prerequisites to check the uptime - this function already special cases the platform app.

During initial investigation of the issue, there were three approaches considered:
1. the current solution to retry
2. check the status of system core pods before attempting to apply
3. wait for extra conductor cycles before applying the app

The problem with 2 is that there is no elegant way to determine which are the system core pods without specifically creating a static list with them. Also, in the future, if there we more system core pods are introduced, that list must also be updated manually.

Solutions 1 and 3 have pretty much the same problem: either waiting another cycle or just retrying a few times doesn't actually give us 100% certainty that the core system pods are actually ready. They also have the same solution: fine-tuning the wait period or retry parameters takes some trial and error. From my testing, the maximum number of tries was 3, so that means that the system should wait another 1 minute and 30 seconds extra in some cases before it does a re-apply.

I like the current solution better because in most cases (over 90% of times), the apply succeeds on first attempt so we shouldn't add extra wait times for something that happens very rarely.

Thanks for the explanation. 

I don't like the current solution - we use retries far too much. Retries should only be a last resort and usually indicate we are not managing our dependencies properly. I don't think that there is any reason we need to be applying the platform-integ-apps so quickly after a reboot and I think the system would be better off to wait a good chunk of time (e.g. several minutes) before doing anything like that.

I'll leave the decision to Bob though as I think he's the expert in this area.
Any potential conflict with this app automatic and repeated apply retries with user-initiated host batch lock/unlock?

The application is still in an "applying state" while retrying is being done. I am not sure if host lock/unlocks take into account application states while doing the operation.

I haven't tested this scenario, as reproducing this issue is very time consuming.
Did you test user initiated application aborts?  I think it looks ok, but would want to make sure that the retry isn't engaged in the case.
I didn't test user initiated aborts and it seems the retry mechanism still triggers. Will update the code with checks for aborts

The description you're giving makes it seem that it isn't like the maintenance flag, though. The maintenance flag bypasses some of the protective checks in state transitions, but doesn't cause any automatically and does not make it so some transitions are off limits. This new thing hides the node in that final "manageable" state, where it is not eligible for scheduling. Setting the flag is also described as triggering state transitions on its own.

If we don't add this to the state machine, how will we document that setting the flag changes those behaviors in the existing states and adds that new transition?

I think what you want is transitions from several of the operational states (active, error, the various versions of "failed", manageable, etc.) via an action like "remove from service", through cleaning, to a state that means the node is unschedulable (maybe that's a good name for the state) but still known to ironic (unlike deleting it). That avoids having effectively 2 versions of the manageable state (one where the node is manageable, and one where it's not actually manageable). It also makes it clear how to get the node into the new state, and what's going to happen to it when that transition happens. Having that clarity is part of the point of the state machine, right?
That would be automatic and would probably the first of this kind. The alternative would be to introduce a completely new state (which is certainly possible, but seemed heavier).

> It sounds like you're adding a flag as a way to add a state, but

"retired" is not a state, it's more like the 'maintenance' flag: one of the main features we need is to be able to set it without changing the state, e.g. when the node is "active", so that the state machine can be followed, e.g. for cleaning, but it is prevented that the node is eligible for scheduling.

 > transition.

specs/keystone/backlog/hierarchical-quot.message: I feel like we have two different defaults here. There seems to be a default for parent or root-level projects (10) and there seems to be a default for all child projects created under that (0). I think the example is fine and it makes sense, but I'm wondering if we need more clarity around each default (if i'm understanding it right).
This fails based on the second rule above, right? The sum of B and C is 15 which exceeds the total limit of A.
meaning there is no limit.
consume*

So one alternate rule that I've mentioned in chat a few times is that the explicit limit could actually be a guarantee. So in the first case below B has an effective limit of 10 because the limit is not set. C would have a guaranteed limit of 5 and D would have a limit of 5. So any children without an explicit limit set share whatever is not already guaranteed by the parent. Of course, the total guaranteed must not exceed the effective limit of the parent. This gets a little complicated in deeply nested hierarchies.
Isn't this one of the thing we didn't like in the Exit Ed model?
I don't think so. Reading why it was rejected it seems like it was rejected because it didn't have the 'unlimited' or 'consume up to the parent limit' idea.
s/by/but/

I should give more description here.

The idea is the operator (global admin) gives a default quota to all parent tenants. The operator can assign the child more quota.

This basically means, the limit on the parent applies to the full tree of users below it.

Now the idea is the operator can allow an admin in that parent tenant to set quota on any of its children. But nothing they does ever gives the subtree of users under that parent any more resources.
The use case is the global operator gives all tenants the default of 10.
Nit: remove this.

The use case here is that the admin in tenant A assigns a limit of 10 to project C.

They have a limit for the whole tree usage to be 10, so that means they have given all quota to only users in project C.
This means it has unlimited access to 0 quota, its totally strange though.
I think they get told that the parent tenant has no quota to give out.

I think the only difference here is that this defaults everyone to -1.

In my proposal I default to the existing default quotas, which could be 10 or -1 for a parent, and -1 for any children.

So you only need to know what the limits is for E, for SUM(D, E, F) and SUM(B, C, D, E, F). You don't need to know anything about the structure of the rest of the tree. Thats what I was trying to describe in my POC.

As E has no limit, technically you don't need to count the resources assigned to E, so in that case I would probably not send anything for E.
I'm not sure I understand how you don't need to count them for E.
+1 for a consistent "ownership" model. That addition was because we lacked project hierarchies.

To check my understanding, moving A to 9 fails because it's direct child B is already at 10, right?

And updating D to 5 is OK because the sum of C (5) and D (5) is <= their parent (B) which is 10. Explaining that would be helpful.

Can a child have multiple parents? If so, I feel like sht is going to get f'ed.
I think I want to add some user based thinking around where I am coming from here.
Your link rendering doesn't work properly here.

nit: I had to read this a couple of times because I expected the tree to look like:

     A
    / \
   B   C
      / \
     D   E

keystone/api/credentials.py.message: So - to make sure I understand it properly. This was failing because policy checks don't filter responses and this policy was being or'd with the deprecated base.RULE_ADMIN_REQUIRED policy?
Yeah - I should have clarified I was referring the behavior of the bug in general.

Not sure which "this" you mean by "this was failing" -

The tempest test was failing on the first patchset because it is testing using the project-admin with enforce_scope=false and expecting that user to be able to list all credentials. This enforcer call wasn't failing in that tempest test, it was the filtering happening below that was over-filtering the results into an empty list.

Or if you're referring to the bug itself, it had nothing to do with rule:admin_required, the problem was that the target is target.credential.user_id.{current_user} which matches the policy check 'or user_id:%(target.credential.user_id)s', so the enforcer here passes - and correct, the enforcer doesn't do any filtering, we were relying on the filtering below. I was hoping the filters=filters could be used somehow here but that only checks the flask query params which aren't the problem here.
Looking at the policy for identity:list_credentials, it's too bad we can't actually leverage the `or user_id:..` bit.
Yeah, it's almost like we need some flag to trigger based on which part of the check string passed the enforcer.

Sure, except at this point the instance.host is pointed at the dest host and it's running there (and that's where the instance mapping is pointing) so I'm not sure how much the lock buys us, but maybe against periodics or something. Anyway, it was copied from the same-cell confirm_resize method.

If you say "trick this code" then I feel that this is a hack. In the other hand if you could say that in reality the instance is already on the dest host we just having access to the instance object from the source host as we are on the source node and therefore we need a temporary mutation, then I fell better about this code. :)

It is a hack because setup_networks_on_host is very hacky. I go into quite a bit of detail about that here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/594139/1/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py@431

Which is for a patch that used a similar hack for a post-live migration rollback scenario.

Looking at how same-cell confirm_resize handles this, it doesn't require the hack because the instance.host is pointing at the dest host but for cross-cell resize the instance we're working with here is in the source cell and still pointing at the source host because we don't update it in case we need to hard reboot/rebuild the source cell instance in case the cross-cell resize fails.

The alternative would be to write a new network API method (delete_port_bindings) which does what setup_networks_on_host does on teardown=True when the port_migrating variable in there is True (and the port_migrating variable is only true if the instance.host and the host passed into the method are different). Or rather than adding a new delete_port_bindings method, we could just implement cleanup_instance_network_on_host which is a pass today for neutron and is only used in the shelve offload case, but maybe that work be OK if it just deleted the port bindings when shelve offloading - otherwise I think we only update the port bindings for a shelved offloaded server when we later unshelve it and update the port binding to the new host on which the server was unshelved.

Anyway, I can try stacking a change on top of the series to see what that might look like and if there would be any fallout.

Let's see how this goes:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697162/

nova/compute/rpcapi.py.message: What is the long running operation in behind this call?

Nothing on its own is probably all that long, though I think the volume attachment delete in cinder is a synchronous call to the storage backend. So it's (1) the pattern we're using fro the cross-cell related compute RPC API methods since the tasks in conductor are orchestrating everything and need to get a response since they aren't polling for changes in the compute and (2) the aggregate of cleanup operations that happen could be longer than the default rpc_response_timeout (60 seconds) especially if there are a lot of ports and/or volumes attached to the server.

<later>

I think the best way of doing it would be:

  filter_properties = {}
  filter_properties['ignore_hosts'] = self._get_hosts_to_ignore(instance, cold_migrate)

where _ignore_hosts is the current _filter_same_host_resize, but it returns [instance.host] or [], depending on its internal logic, and then we could have an easy unit test for _get_hosts_to_ignore that covers all 12 (yes, I counted) possible combinations of cold_migrate (True/False), allow_resize_to_same_host (True/False) and allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host (None/True/False).

nova/conf/workarounds.py.message: I think Dan means this line? And I sorta get his point: if the libvirt driver knows it can't cold migrate to the same host, a workaround config option shouldn't be necessary to communicate that to the rest of the deployment. Which you (Matt) already know, because you did that follow up trait change - this patch is just to make it backportable.

Won't the libvirt op have to set the old thing to True *and* set this to False to make things work? That makes it less useful/sensical as a workaround. It should also probably call that out specifically. And I tend to think the above means it's not really a workaround. I would expect someone not hacking around a problem would have nothing set in their workarounds section, whereas this is more like forcing a workaround off to enable a feature, which seems weird to me.

> Right, so:
 > 
 > - If I'm libvirt, I have the feature enabled already and the bug.
 > To *fix* the bug, I *disable* a workaround
 > - If I'm vcenter, I have the feature enabled already and no bug. To
 > keep working I *enable* a workaround.

If you're vcenter you don't touch this - no change.

 > 
 > Just seems like it's the wrong message in both cases. I'd rather
 > this just not be a workaround, and reno that it's defaulting to
 > None for now, but will default to False in the future and remove
 > the none option.

So you're asking that this just go into the [DEFAULT] group like the allow_resize_to_same_host option? I think it has to default to None for backward compat, which it seems you agree with.

I have it as a workaround because I think we can eventually deprecate and remove the option altogether when we have a trait reported by the computes that the API can use rather than a global option, and that's this:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666604/

So to recap - for my own clarity as much as anything else:

vCenter - want to be able to cold migrate to same host:
allow_resize_to_same_host is already True
allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host is left unset/None, which will default to allow_resize_to_same_host's True.

vCenter - DON'T want to be able to cold migrate to same host:
allow_resize_to_same_host is already False
allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host is left unset/None, which will default to allow_resize_to_same_host's False.

libvirt - allow_resize_to_same_host is False:
The problem necessitating this workaround is never encountered.

libvirt - allow_resize_to_same_host is True:
Might hit bug 1748697 - hope the operators finds the workaround CONF option and sets it, pending upgrade to U, which will include the "real" trait-related fix.

Right, so:

 - If I'm libvirt, I have the feature enabled already and the bug. To *fix* the bug, I *disable* a workaround
 - If I'm vcenter, I have the feature enabled already and no bug. To keep working I *enable* a workaround.

Just seems like it's the wrong message in both cases. I'd rather this just not be a workaround, and reno that it's defaulting to None for now, but will default to False in the future and remove the none option.

> So to recap - for my own clarity as much as anything else:
 > 
 > vCenter - want to be able to cold migrate to same host:
 > allow_resize_to_same_host is already True
 > allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host is left unset/None, which will
 > default to allow_resize_to_same_host's True.
 > 
 > vCenter - DON'T want to be able to cold migrate to same host:
 > allow_resize_to_same_host is already False
 > allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host is left unset/None, which will
 > default to allow_resize_to_same_host's False.
 > 
 > libvirt - allow_resize_to_same_host is False:
 > The problem necessitating this workaround is never encountered.
 > 
 > libvirt - allow_resize_to_same_host is True:
 > Might hit bug 1748697 - hope the operators finds the workaround
 > CONF option and sets it, pending upgrade to U, which will include
 > the "real" trait-related fix.

Correct.

By old thing you mean allow_resize_to_same_host right? If they have that set to True when they get this code, they are already potentially getting the same host for cold migration and failing - that's the bug. This gives them an out by leaving allow_resize_to_same_host=True and changing this new option to False to say, same-host resize - sure go ahead, but disallow cold migration to the same host because I know my deployment doesn't support it.

If you have left allow_resize_to_same_host=False (which it is by default), then you also get allow_cold_migrate_to_same_host=False by default so it's no difference in behavior.

It does mean that we don't get the advantage of shared knowledge between developers though. You'd need to manually check the template/sample file to see if anything new has been added. I think it better to just compromise and to this end, I'm just going to add the checks that Sean suggests because something, even if it's not quite what I'd like, is miles better than nothing.

> Doesn't this framework allow for a user-level config file where
 > Sean or whoever can add their pet rules? Either something outside
 > of the git repos, or an additional file that we can .gitignore?
 > 
 > [Later] Boo, it doesn't look like it.

 > So maybe we should consider adding .pre-commit-config.yaml to
 > .gitignore and renaming this to .pre-commit-config.yaml.sample or
 > something. Yes, it adds an extra step to the default setup (copy
 > the file in your local clone) but then it's customizable.

I'd be concerned that this would be another barrier to entry for using this. I want it to be something that happens automatically without you even need to think about it to maximize the amount of people that will use it. Also YAGNI/KISS.

If the lack of tab autocorrect is a serious blocker, I'd be okay dragging it in to get this in use.

I feel like this discussion motivates making this customizable by individual developers.

If I already have to run two commands to enable this, running three (cp .pre-commit-config.yaml.sample .pre-commit-config.yaml) is not a significant extra burden. It's not like I have to do it every time I want to use it or whatever.

:( ok sthe auto fixing is what i was must looking forward too

or maybe i can locally install that without needing it in the config.

but for the recored we should not have any python code with a 
raw \t in the codebase and we should be use 4 space indentation in all the code.

we do not allow people to commit with tabs
and we always use 4 spaces in nova.

why would we not fix that.
how this works is it auto fixes it and fails the commit so that you have to manually git add them before you can proceed. so you will have the opportunity to review the fix.

im glad the rest are covered however.

> -   id: forbid-crlf

This is handled by the 'mixed-line-ending' plugin.

 > -   id: remove-crlf

I've passed the ['--fix', 'lf'] arguments to the 'mixed-line-ending' plugi so that should take care of this.

 > -   id: forbid-tabs

flake8 does this for us (W191 indentation contains tabs).

 > -   id: remove-tabs

I don't really want to do this since there's a chance there's mixed tabs and spaces and we don't know if the user was seeing a tab as 4 or 8 spaces.

> but for the recored we should not have any python code with a
 > raw \t in the codebase and we should be use 4 space indentation in
 > all the code.

Agreed, but I think highlighting things rather than automatically fixing them is the correct thing to do in this instance. The author's editor is clearly misconfigured so...go fix it? :)

Doesn't this framework allow for a user-level config file where Sean or whoever can add their pet rules? Either something outside of the git repos, or an additional file that we can .gitignore?

[Later] Boo, it doesn't look like it.

So maybe we should consider adding .pre-commit-config.yaml to .gitignore and renaming this to .pre-commit-config.yaml.sample or something. Yes, it adds an extra step to the default setup (copy the file in your local clone) but then it's customizable.

I'm concerned with the use of random github repos in jobs that otherwise should be simple and rocksolid. This introduces the cloning of a repo over the internet in every linter gate job - which increases the likelyhood of spurious failures.

Given the cost of gate resets, I think we should be very careful about such things.

For the primary set of hooks, which pre-commit's design seems built around cloning - if openstack projects are looking at starting to use this tool for real, we could add github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks to zuul so that the cloners can clone it and then add it to required-projects of the linters jobs. We'd also need to add a pre playbook, I'm guessing, that would edit this file if it found it in a repo to replace https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks with /home/zuul/src/github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks ... but since that's a thing that is likely to be in every project using pre-commit, it's maybe a worthwhile investment.

However, I'd argue that a similar investment for a repo that contains a hook for removing tabs, which is a trivial editor setting for every code editor out there, is not.

vmware_nsxlib/v3/cluster.py.message: should we set some retry limit?
do we still need this return statement?

Probably therefore the recursion is not bad, but we should make it safe. Recurring only if we have an available connection might be enough. If another greenlet executes a request and takes that connection:
- if the request succeeds or fails (hitting line 688), then the connection is returned
- if it hits line 698 and therefore the recursive call, the new check we will add will prevent to go into the recursion, and so the connection will be returned to the pool

While this change works, I think it defies the purpose of having a pool, as it allows the client to keep opening unlimited connections until success or exception.

I think this mechanism was conceived to have some sort of built-in rate limiting mechanism.
Maybe using the same retry limit self.nsxlib_config.max_attempts like on line 597?

Or can we just do the retry here?
Maybe create another customized retry_upon_none_result for proxy retry if the existing one taking too long?

openstack_dashboard/api/rest/cinder.py.message:
We shouldn't put this filter logic here since it limits this function can only query the volume snapshots created by bootable volumes.
In my understand, we can first query the 'available and bootable' volumes, then query the 'available' volume snapshots, and get the results you want through these two queries. All handle logic should be implemented in Javascript.

For example [1] and [2]:
[1] https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/static/dashboard/project/workflow/launch-instance/launch-instance-model.service.js#L605
[2] https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/static/dashboard/project/workflow/launch-instance/launch-instance-model.service.js#L613

This is an operation to list volume snapshots, but the proposed change add many API calls. If we have 100 snapshots, this change requires 101 API calls. It introduces a heavy performance problem. This works only small small deployments.

openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/s.message:
That's right. It's also similar to [1]. But even so, we don't need to call the cinder api twice, we only need to get bootable volumes in L:606, since this result contains the data for model.volumes and what you need.
[1] https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/snapshots/tables.py#L42-#L47.

I have to call the cinder api again because the first call filter it and return the available and bootable volumes. In volume snapshot we need all bootable volumes despite if it is available or in-use since the volume snapshot can be taken from in-use volume.

I attach the python code, just agree to the "In volume snapshot we need all bootable volumes despite if it is available or in-use since the volume snapshot can be taken from in-use volume." mentioned in patch set 9.
Okay. In the result from L606  return (available && bootable) volumes so in-use volumes will not be in the result.

The only way to get bootable volume in JS is by calling cinder api  which will return a list of bootable volumes. The code you attached is python and this step is not applicable in JS so I had to call cinder api. Do you have other ways to get bootable volume without call cinder API ?

"The code you attached is python"
# This is the comments for your Patch Set 9.
"Do you have other ways to get bootable volume without call  cinder API ?"
# I've already mentioned it in the previous comments.

"getattr(snapshot._volume, 'bootable', '') == 'true'"
This code can not be used in JS. The getVolumes function call cinder API with two constrains which are available and bootable. In my function I need the bootable despite the status. So I ask you if there is any other way in JS to get bootable volumes.
Doesn't it introduce another new API call to horizon?  We already retrieves a list of volumes (as candidates of boot sources). Can't you re-use it and avoid adding another new API call?

In the previous call, it retrieves the list of (available and  bootable ) volumes. In my function I need to retrieve the bootable volumes despite the status of them so I have to API call with different argument.

The response of volume list operation contains bootable information, so you can calculate a list of bootable volumes without using anther API call. The existing call retrieves all volumes, so a list of bootable volumes can be calculated.

The only call for get volume is:
https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/dc2fd615b580f4ff5c7dfc103dada370ecdf4099/openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/static/dashboard/project/workflow/launch-instance/launch-instance-model.service.js#L606

It return the bootable and available volumes. In my call I need all bootable volume. There is a case where a "in-use" volume have a snapshot , the first api call will not have it in the list, so I had to make a second call to get all bootable volumes despite if there are available or in-use.

Then, how about calling a volume-list API without filtering and filtering properly in the client side to extract appropriate volumes? What you need here is a list of bootable volumes and what the first volume-list API call needs is a list of bootable non-"in-use" volumes, so I still don't think you need two API calls.

On the other hand, if you still think two API calls is useful, I won't request to do so more. This happens only in the launch instance form so I can compromise as the bottom line. If you go to this route, I still would like to see the following before merging the patch.
- JavaScript unit test coverage for this change
- TODO comment on the duplicated API calls for future improvement here.
